abstract.text: Creates a query that monitors the HealthKit store and responds to any changes matching any of the query descriptors you provided.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: An array of descriptors that specifies the types of samples the query returns.
A block that the system calls when a matching sample is saved to or deleted from the HealthKit store. This block takes the following parameters:
A reference to the query calling this block.
A list of data types for all of the changed objects.

If you registered for background updates, call this completion handler as soon as you are done processing the incoming data. This handler tells HealthKit that you successfully received the background update. Additionally, call the completion handler only when you use background updates. For more information on using this completion handler, see
If an error occurs, an object describing the error; otherwise, it’s
error
Use this initializer to create an observer query for changes that match any of the
objects. Each descriptor can specify a different data type.
After instantiating the query, call the
class’s

method to run this query. Observer queries are long-running tasks. They continue to run on an anonymous background thread and call their results handler when the system, the user, or any app adds or deletes a matching sample from the HealthKit store. To stop a query, call the
class’s
method. You can use Observer queries to receive updates in the background. For more information, see

The system calls the update handler block you provide every time something saves or deletes samples matching this query from the HealthKit store. You often need to launch other queries from inside this block to get the updated data. In particular, you can use anchored object queries to retrieve the list of new samples added to the store. For more information, see
For example, the following code monitors the store and calls the update handler after any relevant changes:

code: let stepDescriptor = HKQueryDescriptor(sampleType: stepCountType, predicate: nil)
let pushDescriptor = HKQueryDescriptor(sampleType: pushCountType, predicate: nil)
// Create an inner query to access the changed data.
anchorQuery, samples, deleted, newAnchor, error in
// Process the samples and deleted objects here.

abstract.text: Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the user’s privacy and control.
A query that returns changes to the HealthKit store, including a snapshot of new changes and continuous monitoring as a long-running query.
The access point for all data managed by HealthKit.
A long-running query that monitors the HealthKit store and updates your app when the HealthKit store saves or deletes a matching sample.
Creates a query that monitors the HealthKit store and responds to any changes matching any of the query descriptors you provided.
Instantiates and returns a query that monitors the HealthKit store and responds to changes.
The completion handler for background deliveries.
A descriptor that specifies a set of samples based on the data type and a predicate.
An abstract superclass for all classes that identify a specific type of sample when working with the HealthKit store.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
An unordered collection of unique elements.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.

error
